 CHAPTER 1 BACKGROUND A. Introduction 1.1 Georgia was one of the first republics to leave the former Soviet Union (FSU) when it became independent in April 1991. A small country located in the Caucasus region, Georgia has an area of 70,000 Ian. It is bordered by Turkey and Armenia to the southwest, and by Azerbaijan to the southeast. To the north, there are a number of autonomous republics that form part of the Russian Federation, and the Black Sea borders Georgia to the west. Since 1989, there have been tensions over the status of the autonomous region of Abkhazia, and in 1992 these erupted into open conflict. There have also been disputes with the South Ossetian Oblast since 1990. Currently, both South Ossetia and Abkhazia are outside the Georgian Government's control. 1.2 According to the 1989 census, Georgia's population of 5.4 million is growing at a rate of 0.8% per annum. Average population density is under 80 per km2, but much of the population is concentrated in towns and in the central flat lands. The urbanization rate is high, with over 55 % of the population living in towns; and 27% (1.5 million) live in Tbilisi. Georgia has one of the best educated labor forces in the FSU, with roughly 17.5% of the population having completed post-secondary education. 1.3 Following independence, the country experienced three years of sharp economic decline, financial imbalances leading to hyper-inflation, and political instability. Domestic security problems during this period resulted in severe disruptions of the domestic transport and marketing systems; road blocks and extortion were particularly bad in 1992/93. With the benefit of greater law and order and the restoration of political stability, the Government introduced a program to stabilize and reform the economy in mid-1994, with assistance from the IMF and the World Bank. Since then, considerable progress has been achieved in curbing inflation and stabilizing the external value of the currency. Other major achievements include: (a) the success in privatizing small, medium-sized, and large enterprises, and the decision to dismantle the largest state monopoly in the food and agriculture sector - the State Bread Corporation; (b) the downsizing of the government sector; (c) the adjustment of controlled prices for energy, public transport and bread to levels close to full cost recovery, in order to reduce or eliminate subsidies; (d) the gradual elimination of export restrictions while continuing to maintain a relatively free import regime; (e) the elimination of the state order system; (f) the introduction of a new currency, the Lari, in September 1995; (g) the issuing of new prudential regulations by the National Bank of Georgia along with a new law issued by Parliament guaranteeing the independence of the National Bank in formulating and implementing monetary and exchange rate policies; (h) improvements in the effectiveness of the foreign exchange market by abolishing all distinctions between cash and non-cash, and eliminating the surrender requirement, thus removing implicit taxation of foreign earnings; (i) the introduction of an auction system for foreign exchange; and (j) the introduction of several measures to improve targeting of social benefits in order to maintain a minimum social safety net. 1.4 Georgia has therefore made significant progress in creating a macroeconomic environment conducive to emerging private agriculture and agro-processing industry. The removal of direct state intervention in agricultural production, the abolition of the state order system in 1995, the liberalization of producer and consumer prices, the removal of most restrictions on imports and exports, and the
 2 Chapter I demonopolization of agricultural markets make Georgia one of the least distorted macroeconomic environments in the CIS. The liberal price and trade regime, together with the first signs of overall economic recovery, and positive GDP growth in 1995 and 1996, provide an appropriate environment for the recovery of the food and agriculture sector and for IDA to initiate its first investment project in the sector. B. The Policy Agenda 1.5 Despite the initial success following introduction of the stabilization program described above, the economic situation remains fragile. The tax collection effort remains very weak; the transformation to a market economy is still in an early transition stage; and the productive sector has not fully adjusted to new economic signals. Major measures required to support the Government's continued ability to successfully manage the economy in the near term include: (a) maintaining a tight monetary program supported by an improved fiscal position; (b) streamlining the public sector and efficiently utilizing the limited fiscal resources at the Government's disposal; and (c) fostering a rapid adjustment of the productive sector to new market signals. These three elements are currently being addressed by Government with assistance from the Bank under the Structural Adjustment Credit. Aspects of the third element, which are particularly relevant to the recovery of the agricultural sector and to this project, are briefly described below. 1.6 Privatization of Enterprises. The privatization of state-owned enterprises is one of the most critical elements in the Government's structural reform program. An important step in support of the privatization process is the foreign investment law that was passed by Parliament in June 1995. Except for a selected number of enterprises that are essential to normal government functions, the vast majority of enterprises will be privatized. Rapid progress has been achieved in the privatization of small- scale enterprises, with nearly all such enterprises having already been transferred to private owners by mid-1996. Privatization of medium-and large scale enterprises began in early 1995 with the conversion of 840 enterprises to joint stock companies (which includes 187 out of a total of 440 agro-processing enterprises). Following conversion to joint stock companies, enterprises are privatized. By February, 1997, 515 medium- and large-scale joint stock companies had been privatized. A high priority for the Government at this point is to complete the corporatization of the remaining enterprises awaiting transformation, and the selling of the remaining shares in all medium and large enterprises. The primary method being used to privatize enterprises is voucher and cash auctions; in a few selected cases tenders are also being used. The program does not provide managers and employees special privileges to purchase controlling blocks of shares; they too must compete on an equal basis with all other interested buyers. One exception is the privatization and de-monopolization of the National Bread Corporation, where the Government is proposing to grant managers of mills and bakeries a ten year lease with the option to buy. Since this approach is unlikely to promote competitive behavior in the bread and milling industry, which would benefit the population at large, IDA has recommended to the Government that they reconsider this proposal and use privatization procedures that are consistent with the overall privatization program. Completion of the privatization process, and introduction of supporting legislation wherever necessary, is being assisted by IDA under the Structural Adjustment Credit. Financial support to privatized enterprises, many of which would be in the agro-processing sub-sector, would be provided under the Agricultural Development Project.
 Background 3 1.7 Land Distribution and Privatization. During the Soviet period, about 729,000 families were employed in agricultural production by the state and collective farms. These farms occupied a total of 3,010,000 ha, comprising 797,000 ha of arable land, 320,000 ha under perennial crops, with the balance in pastures and meadows. During this period, 212,000 ha of the arable land was in small subsidiary household plots of up to 0.25 ha per family. The process of land privatization began in January 1992 with Government Resolution 42, generally known as the "Land Privatization Decree." Under this land privatization program, a "privatization reserve" of 852,000 ha (which included those areas already in household plots) was established for distribution to private ownership. While this represents only 33 % of all agricultural land, it includes 83 % of all arable land and 75 % of all land under perennial crops in Georgia. Land was distributed by granting, free of charge, a maximum of 1.25 ha to former employees of state and collective farms and 0.75 ha to other workers in the villages. Urban residents without any land holdings could apply to receive 0.15 ha per family. By the end of 1995, 620,000 ha or about 20% of all agricultural land, which includes 43 % of all arable land and 60 % of all land under perennials, had been distributed to private individuals. The approximately 230,000 ha remaining to be distributed under the 1992 land privatization program are largely in areas where the Government is unable to implement the land reform due to local government opposition in South Ossetia and Abkhazia. In March 1996, Parliament enacted an Agricultural Land Ownership Law that clarifies ownership rights as well as the right to buy, sell, or lease land, thus consolidating the property rights granted under the 1992 land privatization program. Measures supporting the development of a fluid land market by providing owners with a secured title to their land holdings would be introduced under this project on a pilot basis in two districts. 1.8 Land not earmarked for privatization under the 1992 land privatization program is still owned by the State and nominally controlled by State or collective farms. Decree No. 949 of September 1992 required that state and collective farms and enterprises restructure themselves, through the free choice of members and employees, into private farms, cooperative enterprises, or joint stock companies; and that the responsibility for social assets of the farms, such as health clinics, schools and public roads, be transferred to the local authorities. Research and experimental stations, livestock breeding farms, seed farms and other specialized farms were exempt from mandatory restructuring. This decree provided little guidance on the restructuring process itself, resulting in a relatively spontaneous process of restructuring, and a collapse of the State and collective farm system. Much of the land under the control of State and collective farms is presently being used as communal property, is lying idle, or is occupied or leased by individuals on an informal basis. In order to address this problem, the Parliament passed a law on Agricultural Land Leasing in July 1996, which provides for the leasing of State-owned land to individuals on leases of up to 49 years. The law came into force on January 1, 1997. This law is expected to place more agricultural land under private use, thus improving agricultural productivity. 1.9 Establishment of a Land Registration and Land Cadastre System. Under the land privatization program, lists of persons entitled to receive land were developed in many areas, and about 25% of the land owners were issued "Land Owner" certificates. In other areas, however, individuals were assigned users' rights to the land, but no records were kept. Also, where lists exist, they contain many errors, and in most cases, it is impossible to link the certificates to a land parcel. In order to reduce the cost of future disputes and increase the liquidity of land transactions (thus facilitating increased sales, rental, and mortgage agreements on land), it is important to develop a system of land registration and titling. The first step in this process is the establishment of a legal framework to support land registration. Aside from establishing a national land registration system, this law should also include provisions related to: (a) the mortgaging of property; (b) the guarantee of rights of the registered

The Land Registration Law was passed by Parliament in November 1996k meeting a condition for disbursement of the land registration component of this Credit. Regulations related to the law would assign to MAFI the overall responsibility for land registration in rural areas, maintaining a land cadastre system and for recovering the land registration and title costs until such time as an independent land registry is established. 1.11 An integral feature of a land registration system is a mechanism to adjudicate land disputes. Georgia's immediate land adjudication requirements are likely to be different from those of many other countries. While some disputes may arise between occupiers of adjacent plots of land, given the short interval since the occupiers started to cultivate the land, it should be possible to settle many of these disputes in the field during the survey process. Where such disputes cannot be resolved, the surveyors would demarcate the disputed boundary on the map and refer the dispute to the Government for resolution through the justice system. A more common, and potentially much more serious, source of dispute is likely to arise between the occupiers and the State. These disputes will most likely relate to occupiers' encroachment on state land, forest reserves, etc. There may even be boundary disputes between whole villages or adjacent Sakrebulos. This Project would provide training for surveyors in the area of dispute resolution to assist them in their field work. Training seminars for Government officials and the legal establishment on the resolution of land disputes would also be provided. 1.12 Restructuring the Banking Sector. Hyper-inflationary conditions prevailing in Georgia until late 1994 eroded the real values of nominal claims, including the banks' deposits and loan portfolios, as well as confidence in the currency and the banking system. Several measures aimed at restoring confidence in the banking system were recently introduced by the Government under a Bank/IMF financial sector restructuring program. Annex A presents further details on the banking restructuring program. A key feature of the program was the promulgation of a law establishing the independence of NBG to conduct and manage monetary policy. This was followed by a new Commercial Banking Law that gives NBG's supervisors sufficient authority to enforce prudential rules, regulations, and sanctions; regulate mergers and monopolies in the financial markets; and liquidate banks. These expanded powers imply a wider role for the NBG, and for accelerating the strengthening of the legal and regulatory framework for banking in general. 1.13 Government is aware that fostering savings mobilization and efficient intermediation by the banking sector are critical for the economy's recovery, and is therefore intent on furthering reforms. The Agriculture Sector 1.15 Agriculture has traditionally been the mainstay of Georgia's economy. In 1992, the sector employed nearly one third of the labor force and accounted for 33 % of net material product. The main crops grown were cereals, potatoes, horticultural products, and a number of perennials such as tea, grapes, and fruit. Livestock production was another important feature of the sector, accounting for about one third of agricultural output. Overall, however, Georgia experienced a deficit in most livestock products, and had to import substantial quantities of meat and milk. Traditionally, Georgia was a net exporter of food products to the rest of the Soviet Union, with exports exceeding imports by a factor of 7 to 1. Agricultural imports were mainly wheat, sugar, milk and meat. 1.16 Following the collapse of the FSU, the shocks experienced by the Georgian economy were especially pronounced in the agricultural sector, resulting in sharp declines in output and exports. Not only did Georgia lose a sizable segment of the secure and stable market that used to absorb its food products, but it also experienced a disruption of well established trade relationships, resulting in serious difficulties in the system of procurement (agriculture raw materials, energy, packaging materials, parts
 6 Chapter 1 and components, etc.). The end result is that Georgia's trade in agriculture and food products and inputs have been reduced to a small fraction of their pre-independence levels. In response to these developments, the Government lifted many of the administrative restrictions on domestic marketing and movement of goods, and allowed market forces to determine the price of most goods. The remaining controls on the prices of energy are gradually being removed. Subsidization of irrigation water charges through energy is the last remaining producer subsidy in the sector. Agriculture imports are not subject to any restrictions apart from payment of a 12% import duty, which is applied uniformly to most imports. 1.17 The state order system, which underpinned agricultural trade and production, required enterprises producing specified commodities to deliver 65% of their products to the Government at negotiated prices2. By 1995, the system had virtually collapsed, mainly because the state was not able to make timely payments. Delayed payments made in coupons were almost worthless due to hyper- inflation. The system was officially abolished in June 1995. 1.18 Agro-processing and Marketing. The pre-independence agro-processing sector was largely focused on exports to the USSR. Most enterprises were large-scale and state-owned, primarily producing tea (147 companies) and wine (108 companies). Other significant export-oriented enterprises included fruit and vegetable canning, and mineral water bottling. Agro-processing industries geared to the domestic market included the giant State Bread Corporation, which operated a large number of flour mills, bread making plants, feed mills, and poultry raising units. With some exceptions, the machinery and processes used in the agro-processing units were outmoded, and internationally accepted food processing techniques were rarely used. These problems were compounded by the poor quality control and packaging that were tolerated in the captive domestic markets or in the FSU. With the disruption of traditional trading links with the FSU, almost all large-and medium-scale agro-processing units have ceased to function and overall capacity utilization was reported to be about 10% in mid-1996. The main processing activities still functional are flour and bread-making, which are mostly sustained by large amounts of foreign food aid, and a few private sector joint ventures in the areas of wine, fruit juice, and mineral water production and bottling. 1.19 Market Demand for Agricultural Products. While quality standards have been upgraded throughout the FSU region in recent years, and competition from various other countries has intensified, studies conducted by FAO and private consultants indicate that Georgia still has a conparative advantage in providing processed agricultural products to the CIS market. With the reduction in civil unrest in the country, conditions for transport are expected to improve, resulting in a resurgence of exports to the FSU. Good prospects also exist for products with import substitution potential. The most promising products for export and import substitution are in the following areas: wine and brandy production; fruit and vegetable processing; fresh fruits and vegetables; dairy production; cotton processing; mineral water; packaging industry; bread making; and tea processing. The annual export, or import substitution, potential of companies engaged in these areas is estimated to be close to US $1.0 billion. 1.20 Private Farming. Probably the most significant development in the sector since independence has been the emergence of small private farms as the main producers of food and agricultural products. D. Constraints to Increased Agricultural Productivity Credit to Enterprises 1.22 Credit Constraints in Agro-processing and Marketing. With the removal of most of the legal and policy restrictions on trade (para 1.3) and privatization (para 1.6), the primary constraint facing agro-processing and other private enterprises in Georgia is a lack of credit for upgrading technology, and operating funds. A survey of almost 100 agro-processing and marketing enterprises was conducted by a team of consultants, as a preparation activity for this project, to identify the potential demand for credit. This survey identified sDecific project proposals from existing agro-processing and marketing firms which collectively required about US $75 million in credit. While many of these proposals represent relatively large scale projects, even if only sub-loans of less than US $500,000 are considered, the potential demand from 15 out of the 100 companies surveyed would be about US $6.0 million. The survey took into consideration only the current credit needs for existing agro-processing and marketing companies and did not include an analysis of the medium term demand for credit or demand for "greenfield projects." It also did not consider proposals from other sectors, such as agricultural transport, where the current demand for medium term credit is expected to be high. Since there is no loan size limit for onlending under the proposed Credit, the loan is not limited only to agro- processing companies, and new agro-processing companies are expected to emerge over the five year period of the loan, it is reasonable to expect that the effective demand for credit will far exceed the approximately US $10 million in credit available from the proposed IDA Credit and the expected contribution from Participating Banks (PBs), as well as the US $8 million line of credit to be provided by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) under a separate project. This conclusion is further supported by an analysis of outstanding loan applications at five commercial banks in Georgia, carried out by an international consultant group in June 1996, which showed that the value of existing crdt applications at these banks was in excess of US $40 million (of which 70 % is in foreign currency).

A study of six commercial banks in Georgia considered to be potential participants for onlending under this Credit was carried out during Project preparation3. The conclusion of this study is that, collectively, these six banks have a debt capacity of US $60 million (based on capital levels in October 1995). Four of these banks have been appraised and found to substantially meet the conditions required by IDA for Participating Banks. The overriding constraint facing commercial banks in lending for investments is the lack of medium term deposits to match loans of an equivalent duration. This is the result of the recent macroeconomic instability and the lack of domestic depositor confidence in the commercial banking system. The proposed project would address these issues by: (a) pre-qualifying commercial banks to participate in the project after they have completed IAS audits; (b) directly providing them with a line of credit, with maturities from one to five years; and (c) providing, in cooperation with other bilateral donors, technical assistance to banks in all aspects of commercial bank management. Rural Credit 1.24 Background. During the Soviet period, the main supplier of credit to agriculture was the Agrobank, which had over 80 branches. However, the Agrobank was geared to channeling public funds to state enterprises and clearing payments between them, rather than carrying out retail banking operations. Following the breakdown of the FSU's banking system, the rural population lost access to institutional financial services. Over the past three years, there has been virtually no institutional credit available to state and collective farms, nor to individual farmers. Credit to farmns from the agro- processing sub-sector and marketing and input distribution enterprises was also reduced, since they were also facing credit shortages. Finally, self-financing was also reduced, since inflation generated strong upward pressure on prices of purchased farm inputs, while state orders placed a severe constraint on the upward movement of farm commodity prices, causing a severe cost-price squeeze on farm profits. Consequently, utilization of inputs, mainly fertilizers and chemicals, have decreased to an insignificant level, resulting in a sharp fall in crop yields and agricultural production. 1.25 Credit for Small Scale Agriculture. As a result of land distribution and privatization, one of the most critical remaining constraints facing private farms is access to credit. Experience from the one functioning CU in Georgia and the farmers' survey indicate a broad and substantial demand for credit on the part of the rural population, with 60 % of the farmers in the survey indicating that they had a need for credit, in varying amounts up to Lari 4,000 (US $3,333), with the most commonly requested credit terms being 12 - 24 months at interest rates of 1-2 percent per month. Given the size of these farm operations, loans of this size would be for on-farm investments, with loans of Lari 200 - 300 expected for seasonal input loans. Given the current nominal interest rates of 3-4% per month (and real interest rates of 1-2% per month), borrowing would be limited to short term seasonal input loans that yield significant marginal returns in 4 to 6 months. Investment borrowing is expected to increase over the five years of the project, as the nominal and real interest rates decline under the economic stabilization program. 1.26 Included in the farmers' survey was an analysis of the use and impact of the following selected purchased inputs (figures in parentheses indicate the percent of farms that purchased these inputs): fertilizers (28%), chemicals (34%), veterinary services and drugs (25%), and animal feed (47%). 3 Peter Marion, October 1995. Based on the results, net farm incomes can be expected to increase by the following percentage with the use of purchased inputs: fertilizers (35%), chemicals (10%), veterinary drugs and services (17%); and animal feed (47%). Except for farms purchasing chemicals, the percent of profitable farms was between 10 and 15% higher where purchased inputs were used when compared with those that did not purchase inputs. The substantial marginal returns from the use of purchased inputs at these levels of output provides an underlying basis for the results of the farmers' survey which indicate a strong demand for credit. It also demonstrates that farmers could pay interest rates of up to 3-4 % per month on seasonal credit for a typical input package costing between 200 and 300 Laris. 1.27 Formation of a Rural Credit System. Failure of the banking sector to serve individuals seeking credit has been particularly acute in the agriculture sector. In the few isolated cases where credit is available, interest rates are beyond the repayment capacity of most borrowers. At present, NBG's capital requirements for establishing new banks prevents the establishment of small rural banks. Furthermore, private banks in urban areas lack the resources and interest to expand their networks to the rural communities. At the same time, the former state banks have no experience in lending to large numbers of small farmers and lack the financial resources to operate the branches at their command. Underlying these actions is the reluctance of the banking sector to lend to farms because of: (a) the high transaction cost of small scale rural lending; (b) the lack of secure collateral; and (c) inexperience in assessing the risk of agricultural lending. The proposed project would address these constraints by promoting the establishment of small rural CUs, which would rely on local knowledge of the borrower to assess risk, reduce the need for collateral, and reduce transaction costs. Experience in other countries with similar rural traditions, such as Albania, has shown that CUs can play a vital role in mobilizing local financial resources to make small individual loans to their members (typical loans are less than US $500 and for periods of 3 to 12 months), which often include not only farmers, but small traders and micro- entrepreneurs. Lending to non-farm enterprises and the fact that farm households derive a substantial proportion of household income from non-farm sources (pjar 1.21), combined with training in portfolio management for CU managers, will enable the CUs to significantly reduce the covariance risk typically faced by specialized agricultural lending institutions. The proposed land registration component of the project would also improve access to credit by providing a more secure form of collateral if needed for larger capital investments. Land Markets 1.28 In order to achieve efficient use of agricultural land, through market allocation to the most efficient users, there is a need to establish a land market that permits the low cost transfer of land on a permanent basis, through sales, or on a temporary basis through the rental agreements. A system that provides low cost verification of ownership and encumbrances on land, and the transfer of title in the event of default, provides the basis for mortgage based lending. The land reform program being undertaken in Georgia has established the basis for a land market in agricultural land, through the privatization of land under the Land Privatization Decree of 1993 and the Agricultural Land Leasing Law of 1996, and the confirmation of private property rights under the Agricultural Land Ownership Law of
 10 Chapter 1 1996. However, the lack of clearly defined title to land in Georgia, increases the uncertainty associated with land sales or rental agreements, thus increasing the transaction cost of land transfers and restricting the market for land. The high cost of ownership verification and the difficulty of transferring untitled land make mortgage lending on land prohibitively expensive for commercial banks. A title registration system to reduce the transaction cost of land transfers and mortgage lending would be developed under the project. Agricultural Support Services 1.29 The lack of appropriate technologies for private agriculture, including farming methods, inputs, machinery, and management techniques, will continue to be a major constraint on agricultural productivity, unless the Government makes a concerted effort to provide support services to farmers. The structure of the current research and information dissemination system, which was designed to support large scale state managed agriculture, is not well suited to supporting small scale private farms and is currently on the point of collapse. An extension system per se never existed in the planned economy. Animal health services and sanitary inspection previously provided by MAFI have also ceased to function. The proposed project would support the development of an agricultural sector strategy and investment program through training for government officials in economic policy analysis and a series of studies and small pilot operations to identify the constraints to increased agricultural productivity. Strategy for Assistance in the Agricultural Sector 1.31 The Bank completed an Agriculture and Food Sector Review Report in August 1995 that recommends a set of actions to facilitate recovery in the sector. It also provides guidelines for replacing the present spontaneous and unstructured sectoral reforms with a structured and consistent program for transition to a market based agriculture. Specific policy recommendations included in the report cover the following aspects: (a) completing land reform and farm restructuring by: (i) completing the distribution of land to private owners; (ii) clarifying the legal status of land distributed under the 1992 land reformn decree; (iii) transferring the remaining state-owned land and the non-land productive assets to private users and operators; and (iv) creating conditions for a functioning land market; (b) developing a working competitive domestic market for agricultural products and agriculture sector services, required to accelerate the: (i) privatization of farming and agro-industrial enterprises; (ii) de-monopolization of the distribution, input supply, and product markets; and (iii) facilitation of the entry of foreign capital and firms into domestic agro-processing, input distribution and support services; (c) creating a financial intermediary system that can meet the agricultural sector's credit needs; and
 12 Chapter 1 (d) developing an institutional framework that is consistent with the needs of a market-based agriculture and includes: (i) changing the Government's role in the sector from one that has traditionally administered and managed a command economy, to a more hands-off role of supporting the private sector through regulation, research and analysis, and the provision of public goods and services; (ii) creating a new institutional framework for a working agricultural market, including commodity exchanges, market information systems, etc; and (iii) developing an extension service, research, and education focused on the needs of privatized agriculture. 1.32 Specific measures to implement the policy recommendations outlined above are incorporated in the Structural Adjustment Program. Lessons Learned from Past Operations in the Agticultural Sector 1.33 The proposed project is IDA's first operation supporting Georgia's agricultural sector. A number of projects in the ECA Region were examined during the design phase of this project. The most important one was a 1994 Agricultural Reform Implementation Support Project in Russia that is designed to accelerate agricultural reforms; strengthen agricultural support services, including the creation of a land administration and management service; build-up institutional capacity to prepare and implement agricultural and agri-business projects by the private sector; and to develop market information systems and farmers' advisory services. Design of the Georgia project also took into account the experience gained under the 1993 Rural Poverty Alleviation Pilot Project in Albania and a subsequent 1995 Rural Development Project. Both of these projects contain small-scale credit components and their experience was taken into consideration during the design phase of this project. Implementation of the pilot small- scale credit component in Albania was judged by OED to be satisfactory, its sustainability assured, and its impact on institutional development substantial. Component 1: Credit to Enterprises (US $12.0 million) 2.5 The Line of Credit. The line of credit to enterprises (CE) would be supervised by the Credit to Enterprises Unit (CEU) under the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and made available to participating banks (PBs) who would sign subsidiary loan agreements with the Ministry of Finance. A PB would be accredited by IDA to participate in the project after meeting a set of predetermined accreditation criteria (para. 3.23), which would assess the bank's financial viability measured against international accounting standards (IAS), adequate management strengths, capability to assess credit and risks, credit absorptive capacity, and adherence to the NBG's prudential banking standards. The line of credit to enterprises would finance fixed investments and associated working capital. Proposed on-lending terms and conditions to the PBs are described below. In addition, a portion of the CE would be used to finance the PCU's expenses related to the management of this component and the engagement of an internationally experienced advisor who would assist the CEU to manage the CE. The operating costs for the CEU would be funded from the Special Account for Project Administration (the same way as the rest of the PCU) and CE allocation, which would be for onlending to commercial banks. While this line- of-credit is available to any private enterprises engaged in economic activities in rural areas, it is expected that a majority of the funds will be used by agribusiness companies since they make up an estimated 75 percent of all enterprises in Georgia, and, in addition, there will be an aggressive program to assist agriculture related companies prepare business plans and loan applications, thus gaining access to the line- of-credit. The goal of the project is to promote the demand for credit by agro-processing companies rather than impose supply side restrictions (targeting) by limiting its use to these companies. 2.6 Government On-lending Terms and Conditions. PB's would have the option of borrowing (and lending) project funds in either dollars or Laris. Dollar denominated borrowings by PBs would be at a floating rate, to be adjusted semi-annually, of LIBOR plus 3.0 percentage points, of which 0.3 of a percentage point would cover the CEU's administrative costs and 2.7 percentage points would be for a risk fund to provision for PBs potential payment default. The line of credit to enterprises would be for sub-loans with term-to-maturities of up to five years for fixed investments and working capital. For enterprises, training included: organization and management; accounting and finance; project preparation; marketing and sales; legal and contractual practices and procedures; corporate restructuring; and banking practices and corporate relationships. The experience of the Albania Rural Poverty Alleviation Project (1993) and the subsequent Rural Development Project (1995) would suggest that "learning by doing" approach to the development of a rural credit union system is highly successful. Benefits 4.1 The primary beneficiaries of this project are expected to be private enterprises engaged in economic activities related to the rural sector, including agribusinesses, small-scale rural businesses, small-scale private farmers and rural landholders. The line of credit, which would be used primarily by agribusiness companies, is expected to result in large gains in productivity by allowing firms to upgrade their technology and providing them with operating capital. The establishment of CUs in rural areas would benefit both small farmers and small-scale rural businesses by establishing a low cost mechanism for non-collateral based lending. An estimated 46,000 farm owners who live in the project area, 36,000 urban dwellers who received small parcels of land under the land reform program, and 48,000 part time rural residents who received small land allocations during the soviet period would be the main beneficiaries of the land registration component. With an average farm size of 0.9 hectares, most of the farm families are in the bottom half of the income strata in Georgia. Land titling would be a particularly important social safety net for older land owners, who could generate income by leasing their land, knowing that they have secure title. In the longer run, title registration is expected to increase the liquidity of the land market by reducing the cost of land transactions, thus increasing the productivity of small-scale agriculture in Georgia. 4.2 Although the project is expected to generate substantial benefits, it is not possible to measure these benefits with a conventional economic analysis. However, with the removal of financial distortions and subsidies agreed recently under the Structural Adjustment Credit, and with sub-loans to enterprises required to have a minimum financial rate of return of 15%, the project is expected to yield a rate of return higher than the opportunity cost of capital. The project would also have a positive impact on Government's revenues due to the increase in the tax base to be brought about by the land registration program and the improved incomes of both enterprises and farmers. Enterprises: (a) Rehabilitation of enterprises, thus increasing productivity of existing investments; (b) Increase in foreign investments and the creation of joint ventures leading to the transfer of technology to Georgia; (c) Development of a capacity to expand exports, compete in foreign markets, and enable enterprises to be more efficient and productive; and (d) Improvements in the revenue, management, and productivity of enterprises.

Agreements reached last year under the IMF Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility and the IDA Structural Adjustment Credit should help alleviate this risk. In the event of a serious regression in the macroeconomic reform program, serious consideration would need to be given to cancelling the credit components of the project. C. Sustainability 4.5 The project's basic rationale is that the agriculture sector should, over time, become self- sustaining without having to rely on govermnent subsidies and protective measures. Thus, loans to enterprises would be at positive real interest rates, with private banks bearing the full commercial risk. Similarly, loans to members by CUs would be structured so as to minimize current distortions in rural credit by making them positive in real terms and linking interest rates to the cost of funds and to the CUs' operating expenses. Except for an initial grant to help establish the CUs, and funding shortfalls in the CUDC, interest rates would be structured so as to cover all operating costs. Efforts would also be made to establish a foundation of agricultural services based as far as possible on the principle of full cost recovery. 4.6 Over time, sustainability of the land registration program would depend on the capacity to recover the registration costs from land owners and the ability to mobilize the private sector to undertake the survey work. Both of these aspects are an integral feature of the project and if they are successful, it should be possible to make the program self financing and to expand it rapidly to other parts of the country.

The approach of the Government to restructuring the financial sector has been to rapidly privatize all state owned banks, establish a set of prudential regulations to regulate all banks, restrict the activities of non-compliant banks, and implement an agreed timetable for the restructuring of the three Former State-owned Banks (FSBs). Status of the Banking Sector 2. A major weakness in the banking sector has been the distressed financial position of the remnants of the FSBs, which control a significant proportion of the assets in the sector. Diagnostic studies and audits of these banks -- United Georgian Bank (the merged Savings Bank, Industrial Bank,and Exim Bank), Bank of Georgia, and Agro Bank-- show that they have high levels of bad loans. Their poor financial performance can be attributed to their role as state banks, a failure to carry-out adequate risk assessment and creditworthiness analysis of borrowers, and their inability and unwillingness to enforce the collateral liquidation procedures and security collection on non-performing assets. Weak management, inappropriate organizational structures, and outmoded operating systems have also contributed to their current situation. Given the potential economy-wide implications of the failure of one of these institutions, and the implicit guarantees that their deposits carry, the Government has agreed to a timetable of targets which each bank should meet in order to move towards compliance with the NBG prudential requirements. In the last year, two of these banks, United Georgian Bank and Bank of Georgia have made significant progress toward meeting these prudential requirements. Agro Bank has been slower to adjust. 3. Many small, private commercial banks have emerged since early 1992 and have been gaining market share. They currently control between 35 and 50 percent of the total assets in the banking system. There has also been a significant consolidation of the banking sector due to the introduction of NBG's banking prudential standards, including a US$100,000 minimum capital requirement for all banks. As of November 1996 there were 65 banks operating in Georgia compared to 88 in April 1996 and 229 in March 1995. Of the 65 banks operating, 45 have been certified by the National Bank of Georgia. A further decline in the number of banks is expected over the next few years as a result of the continued implementation of the NBG bank certification program and the new US$500,000 minimum capital requirement that will become effective in June, 1998. The impact of such a sharp reduction in the number of banks is not expected, however, to lead to sector-wide systemic risks since most of the liquidated or reorganized banks had very few customers or assets. Assessment of the Banks 4. The Former State Banks: Many of their current problems stem from poor portfolio performance during their tenure in the public sector. These problems have been compounded by poor lending decisions based on inadequate risk assessment policies, failure to carry-out adequate loan

It is estimated that over 60 percent of the total loan portfolio of FSBs is non-performing. While two of the FSBs have undergone restructuring and have made significant strides toward meeting the NBG prudential requirements, Agro Bank continues to have major problems with its portfolio and with its capital adequacy. As part of the restructuring process, Bank of Georgia has been fully privatized and the privatization of United Georgian Bank is almost complete. Agrobank is also in the process of being privatized but the Government still owns 27 percent of its shares. Investors and donors are being sought to obtain the necessary funds for the private recapitalization and restructuring of these banks. The equity position of United Georgian Bank improved last year with a significant foreign investment in the Bank. It was also able to write down a significant proportion of its bad debt during 1996. 5. The Private Commercial Banks: Data from the four commercial banks appraised for this project suggest that there are a small but growing number of well managed and sufficiently capitalized banks that could operate profitably under the current difficult environment. As of December 1, 1996 each of the four banks had completed International Accounting Standards (IAS) audits and were found to substantially meet the minimum requirements for participation under the line of credit (para 3.23). These banks will still require heavy technical assistance to bring them up to western banking standards. They will also continue to have IAS audits; undergo improvements in their operating policies and procedures, as required by the conditions of their respective subsidiary loan agreements; and conform with NBG prudential standards. At least four additional banks are expected to convert to IAS auditing procedures in 1997. Strategy for the Banking Sector 6. The banking strategy addresses three sets of issues: (a) the restructuring of the former state banks; (b) preventing non-viable banks from expanding until they have met NBG's prudential requirements; and (c) the strengthening of NBG and its supervisory and regulatory powers. 7. The large size of the FSBs in relation to the private banks and the fact that they carry an inheritance of non-performing loans from their time in the state sector means that a number of additional issues must be factored into the strategy for their restructuring. This strategy is defined by a set of procedural rules ( i.e. IAS audits, portfolio due-diligence, loan work-outs, institutional building, and capital raising) and a timetable for complying with these regulations. In the application of these rules, there is a recognition that the strategy will take time to implement and that these banks may only return to financial health in the medium term, if at all. During this restructuring period the NBG might be placed in a position of having to provide ad-hoc financial intervention until these problems are resolved. 8. The strategy for the restructuring of private commercial banks will be the strict enforcement of minimum capital and prudential standards thus raising the standards of the banking system. This will be achieved through (a) strengthening of NBG bank certification procedures; (b) introducing IAS audit and portfolio due-diligence requirements; (c) enforcing strict compliance with prudential rules and regulations; and (d) providing training for banks in loan analysis and credit administration designed to prevent the re-emergence of a large number of non-performing assets. The liquidation and merger of smaller banks will result from the need to increase minimum capital requirements and

Two approaches to land boundary survey are possible. One is a "General Boundary" approach. This approach is suitable where boundaries between parcels of land are physically occupied on the ground by features such as fences, walls, ditches or banks and where these features are identifiable on an aerial photograph. In the two rayons of Gardabani and Mtskheta, it is estimated that the 94,000 parcels comprising Summer Houses and Rural Families Holdings in Villages, have physically marked boundaries most of which will be identifiable on rectified aerial photographs. It was therefore decided to survey these parcels with "General Boundaries". Using this approach, boundary corners will be identified on the ground and marked on the aerial photographs. Land holders would be invited to join the surveyors and any disputes regarding the location of the boundary will be settled in the field. The boundaries will be digitized from the photographs to determine co-ordinates and areas, and a line-map of all parcels will be produced. Owners who require more precise survey measurements of their boundaries will be free to employ a surveyor to undertake that task. Survey results would subsequently be maintained in a Land Registry Office. The advantages of this approach are low costs, speed and simplicity. 12. The second approach to land boundary survey to be utilized by the project is a "Coordinate Based Field Survey" system. Under this system the dimensions and areas of individual holdings would be measured and calculated and corner markers placed in the ground. With the help of the Geodetic Survey Coordinates, surveyors would determine the boundary coordinates of each parcel. An estimated 105,000 parcels in the two project rayons comprise agriculture land holdings belonging to urban residents and rural families. The boundary of these parcels are not physically marked and will need to be surveyed in the field. Here too, disputes would be adjudicated in the field by the surveyors and the survey results maintained in the Land registry. Both the "general boundary" and the "co-ordinate based" system would have the capability to store the deeds and the parcels' layout in a computer. A system of parcel numbering would be developed to ensure that each parcel is allocated a number that is unique to it. The numbering system will be on a village basis. The estimated cost for field survey and production of titles for general boundaries is US$ 8.6 per parcel (Table 7a) and for co-ordinate based field survey US$ 20.5 per parcel (Table 7b). 13. Benefits. Based on other countries' experience with similar land registration and titling programs, the main benefits to be derived from the project include: improved tenure security against unfair land acquisition; ability to sell land at fair market prices; increased access to institutional credit arising out of the ability to use land as collateral; more intensive use of farm inputs; acceleration in the rate of on-farm investments; more efficient land markets and hence improved resource allocation; higher land productivity and beneficiary income; and reduction in conflicts over land rights. 33. The project would also provide the foundation for GOG's long-term land registration and land management program. Over time such a program is expected to foster a more efficient and equitable land market in Georgia in terms of: more efficient and transparent land transactions; reduced risks in land-related investments; mobilization of financial resources through the use of land as collateral; a more objective basis for land valuation and a standardized land information system; and encouragement to longer term investments in land improvements leading to more productive land use. The introduction of an efficient land registration system also has a fiscal impact. Socio-economic studies conducted in various counties show conclusively that the introduction of land registration results in substantial increases in revenues collections. Thus land registration can become a cost effective way to increase government's revenues without raising the unit rates of land taxes and transfer fees.

Consider options for promoting Georgian products in international markets, through international promotions, upgrading of trade offices, etc. Examine the transport and loading facilities for exports and make recommendations for improvement. Resources Foreign Consultants, 6 person-weeks National Consultants, 10 person-weeks Cost Estimates US$ 35,000
 Annex E Page 6 of 10 IV. Socio-Economic Studies to Monitor the Effects of Land Reform Obiective Two studies, one conducted shortly before the mid-term review and the second after project implementation completion, will be used to monitor the progress of the land reform program. The study will review a broad spectrum of issues related to land reform. Scope of the work 1. Conduct a national survey to ascertain the status of the land reform program. Results from this survey should, inter alia, provide information on: progress in land privatization, leasing of state lands, and the development of land rental and land mortgage markets, the proportion of land held by the private sector, the size of land holdings, the proportion of leased to owned land; information on land titling and dispute resolution; the use of land as collateral; the number of land sales and rentals on titled and untitled land; the distributional effects of land reform, including the impact of the reform on women and elderly; farmers access to credit and inputs; status of public services (health, education, roads); and improvement in productivity. 2. Prepare a report summarizing the findings of the survey. Resources Foreign Consultants, 12 person-weeks National Consultants, 80 person-weeks Cost Estimates US$ 100,000
 Annex E Page 7 of 10 V. Training Program for Small-Scale Rural Entrepreneurs Obiective With the privatization of agriculture in Georgia, a majority of ex-employees of state and collective farm are participating in private sector business activity, including farming. While most of these people are well educated and some have good technical agriculture training, they have had little or no exposure to managing a private sector enterprise. The objective of this study is to develop and test a program of business training, both formal and informal, for small scale rural entrepreneurs, including farmers. Scope of the work. 1. Review and evaluate the quality and quantity of existing formal and informal training programs in farm management. 2. Evaluate the management training needs of small-scale rural entrepreneurs. 3. Recommend a management program for small-scale business that would include: Proposals for a training of trainers program; Outline of short and long term training courses (including course curriculum, appropriate text books and training materials, teaching methods, etc.); and Organizational arrangements for delivering the training, together with staffing requirements, budgets, sources of financing; number of persons to be trained and an initial four year training program. Resources: International Consultant, 3 person-weeks National Consultant, 10 person-weeks Cost estimates: US$ 20,000

Study to Develop a Depositors' Insurance Scheme for Rural Credit Unions Objective The objective of this study is to develop an insurance scheme that would insure a proportion of depositors deposits in the event that a rural credit union is declared bankrupt. Scope of Work 1. Analyze the structure and experience of existing rural credit unions in Georgia and make recommendations on whether a deposit insurance scheme is necessary. If so, recommend the most appropriate program, taking into consideration the moral hazard issues inherent in insurance schemes, and the impact that this would have on the group lending discipline of Credit Unions; the risk of political interference and moral hazard associated with having a government backed insurance program; the lack of a developed private sector insurance industry in Georgia; the effect that an insurance program(or lack thereof) would have on depositor confidence and therefore on the level of deposits collected by CUs; 2. Recommend appropriate institutional structures, laws and prudential regulations for managing the deposit insurance scheme. 3. Conduct a detailed financial and actuarial analysis of the expected risk of default for Rural Credit Unions and appropriate insurance fees needed to cover these risks, in order to ensure that the insurance program is sustainable.  Annex F Credit to Enterprises Unit Function of Credit to Enterprises Unit (CEU) 1. The functions of the CEU are to: (a) Facilitate the signing of subsidiary loan agreements between MOF and PBs that will onlend funds under the IDA credit line, monitor their on-going eligibility in close consultation with the NBG Supervision Department, and propose remedies and impose corrective measures and sanctions on PBs falling out of compliance with the terms and conditions of the Subsidiary Loan Agreements. (b) Develop and maintain the operating policies and procedures, manuals, database, accounting systems and other information systems for managing and reporting on the line of credit. (c) Facilitate and monitor the technical assistance (TA) and other technical support provided to the PBs. (d) Implement and advise on disbursement and procurement procedures and arrangements, ensuring compliance with IDA rules, and provide disbursement and procurement reports to IDA based on agreed schedules. (e) Maintain the project accounting records, and arrange for regular audits of the project accounts. (f) Monitor repayments of funds on-lent to PBs by MOF under the terms and conditions of the subsidiary loan agreements, and ascertain that the repayments will be available for further on-lending. (g) Confirm that disbursement requests comply with all eligibility requirements, the required legal documents and signatories, and approve requests for disbursements under the project. (h) Conduct post-facto reviews, and report findings to IDA according to specific agreements, on the PBs' accounting of the sub-loans and the utilization of the credit line. (i) Ensure that all other compliance requirements under the IDA line of credit are met. (j) Provide advisory services to agribusiness companies in the areas of business planning and preparation of loan applications.

(c) The Accounting Manager will be responsible for: Setting up the project accounts, accounting system and related documentation controls; Authorizing disbursements to/from the 'special account' based on loan payments; Arranging for IAS audits on all sub-project accounts by an acceptable independent audit firm; Collecting repayments from subsidiary loans; and Reporting, as required, on project disbursement and collection performance under the credit line. (d) Enterprise Manager The enterprise manager will be responsible for: Assisting agribusinesses prepare business plans; Assisting agribusinesses prepare loan applications for the IDA line of Credit; Advise agribusiness companies on available private sector consultants; and Advise agribusiness companies on the availability of the Georgian Private Investment Center. doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Agricultural Development Project is to increase agricultural productivity in Georgia by supporting the development of private sector farming and agro-processing. The specific goals are to develop an agricultural credit system; facilitate increased liquidity in land markets; and identify an agricultural development and investment program to address major constraints to increasing agricultural productivity. To support the above objectives, the project will provide financing to the Project Coordinating Unit and to four free-standing components. Three of these components: a) Credit to Enterprises; b) Credit Unions; and c) Agricultural Services, will have nation-wide coverage. The Land Registration component will be limited to two administrative districts (rayons) in the vicinity of Tbilisi.
